author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Home of a Massive Flock
description: Ryan McCarty takes some risks, but ends up pleasing the crowd.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Am I preaching to the choir when I say, “phew”? It feels like weeks since I’ve seen a Saturday grid I can actually break into, instead of breaking into a cold sweat. Maybe we’ve paid our penance. Ryan McCarty has constructed a positively fearless puzzle with a big, splashy set of debuts that are bound to evoke a strong reaction of one kind or another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amir Jalal Zerdoumi and Carlotta Gall
title: Abdelaziz Bouteflika, Algeria’s Longest-Serving President, Dies at 84
description: He joined the country’s fight for independence in the 1950s and helped lead it out of a brutal civil war in the 1990s. He was ousted in 2019 after 20 years in office,
content: ALGIERS — Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who joined his country’s fight against French colonial rule in the 1950s, rose to foreign minister at 26, went into exile over corruption charges and then returned to help lead the nation out of civil war, has died, He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Yolanda López, Artist Who Celebrated Working-Class Women, Dies at 78
description: She was celebrated for recasting the Virgin of Guadalupe in her own image as a feminist superhero — a young, strong, brown woman in running shoes.
content: Yolanda López, an artist and activist who created one of the most famous artworks in Chicano history by boldly recasting the Virgin of Guadalupe in her own image — as a young, strong, brown woman wearing running shoes and a wide grin — died on Sept. 3 at her home in San Francisco. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Harassed and Harangued, Poll Workers Now Have a New Form of Defense
description: Threatened by extremists and under fire by politicians, election workers now have their own legal defense network. It’s a perk they never expected to need.
content: WASHINGTON — It is perhaps a metaphor for the times that even the volunteer who checked you into the polls in November now has a legal defense committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hard
title: Lions and tigers at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo test positive for the virus.
description: It is unclear how the animals were infected.
content: Lions and tigers and Covid? Oh my. Some of the lions and tigers of the Smithsonian’s National Zoo & Conservation Biology Institute in Washington, D.C., have tested positive for the virus that causes Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Never Complain, Never Explain
description: Drop the Identity Cloak when identity is not the issue. (And tax the rich!)
content: What ever happened to the good old-fashioned art of Owning It?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Takeaway Crossword
description: Alex Eaton-Salners resurrects a fu* diversio*.
content: TAKEAWAY CROSSWORD — Today we have a real novelty, a puzzle that puts our deductive ability to the test in a way that looks simple but develops into satisfying complexity. I went to the archives to see if it was new, and found that The New York Times has run three of them before, all by Matt Ginsburg, between 2009 and 2015. Alex Eaton-Salners constructed today’s grid; variety connoisseurs may be reminded of another of his specialties, the “Going Too Far” puzzles. Easy directions lead to a creative workout and a challenging solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Malin
title: Having Trouble Finding Your Soul Mate? Let Mom Do It For You.
description: As vaccine rollout continues, the pressures of online dating are back. So is the idea of outsourcing the matchmaking to your Jewish parents.
content: It’s no secret that online dating can be a stultifying, painful and sometimes traumatizing experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Rep. Lee Zeldin Confirms Leukemia Diagnosis
description: Mr. Zeldin, a conservative Republican, says the disease is in remission, and that his bid for governor of New York will be unaffected.
content: Representative Lee Zeldin, a staunch conservative from Long Island and the leading Republican candidate in next year’s race for governor in New York, revealed that he was diagnosed with leukemia last year and has been receiving treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Karsten Moran
title: A Week After the Open, Championship Tennis Continues in Queens
description: A Davis Cup tie between South Africa and Venezuela is being held in front of a small group of fans at the West Side Tennis Club — the first Davis Cup action there since 1959.
content: A week has passed since the United States Open electrified the tennis world with its enchanting unpredictability and rejuvenated fan base. But unknown to many, top flight tennis lingered in New York City as the Davis Cup made a quiet and unusual return to the West Side Tennis Club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brennan Carley
title: Jeff Probst Is the Ultimate ‘Survivor’
description: Despite many changes to the reality show over the last 21 years, he has been a constant.
content: Jeff Probst was halfway to Fiji when he got the call. It was mid-March 2020, days before “Survivor” was scheduled to begin filming, and he was on vacation with his family in Hawaii when he learned that months of work and preparation would have to be suspended immediately. The show’s crew — around 400 people — were suddenly out of work. Plans to shoot the show domestically were investigated and scrapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau Seeks a Fresh Start, but Many Voters See a Power Grab
description: A snap election that was supposed to be a show of strength has instead allowed opponents to highlight the prime minister’s weak points.
content: BURNABY, British Columbia — Outside a TV studio in a Vancouver suburb where Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada was recording an interview days ahead of the country’s election, a man shouted insults, mostly obscene, about Mr. Trudeau and his family while blasting Twisted Sister’s “We’re Not Gonna Take It” from a stereo on a cart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins and Alissa J. Rubin
title: First Tied to ISIS, Then to U.S.: Family in Drone Strike Is Tarnished Twice
description: The U.S. admission that a drone strike that killed 10 civilians was a “tragic mistake” did nothing to ease the sense of vulnerability among surviving family members and co-workers living under Taliban rule.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Pentagon’s admission of having made a “tragic mistake” in the killing of an Afghan aid worker, and seven children from his extended family in a drone strike, added one more incident to the long, grievous list of U.S. military mistakes in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What if Covid Were 10 Times Deadlier?
description: Would a deadlier pandemic have yielded different political divides?
content: “I think I’ve come to believe that even if the Covid death toll was 10 times what it currently is,” the MSNBC host Chris Hayes wrote a few days ago on Twitter, “the politics of all of it wouldn’t be appreciably different.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Joe Manchin Got the Voting Bill He Wanted. Time to Pass It.
description: Congress needs to protect voting rights. Now.
content: Far too many Republicans are players in a cynical pantomime: They say that the new voting restrictions being passed across the nation are designed solely to thwart widespread voting fraud, when the reality is that widespread fraud does not exist and the new restrictions’ purpose is to frustrate and disadvantage voters who lean Democratic — especially minority, young and lower-income voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Shane Goldmacher
title: In Orange County, the Recall’s Defeat Echoes Years of G.O.P. Erosion
description: Voters struck down the effort to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom, continuing the political seesawing that has defined the former Republican stronghold.
content: LADERA RANCH, Calif. — When Gail Grigaux first moved to Ladera Ranch in Orange County from the East Coast more than 15 years ago, she knew she had arrived in the conservative heart of Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Matthew Rosenberg
title: Sparse Right-Wing Protest of Jan. 6 Arrests Draws Huge Police Response
description: Organizers said the police response had dampened turnout for the “Justice for J6” rally, which served as a platform for pro-Trump politicians seeking House seats next year.
content: WASHINGTON — Fewer than 100 right-wing demonstrators, sharply outnumbered by an overwhelming police presence and even by reporters, gathered at the foot of the Capitol on Saturday to denounce what they called the mistreatment of “political prisoners” who had stormed the building on Jan. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Lawmakers, After a Rightward Shift, Plan for More of the Same
description: The state recently completed one of its most conservative legislative sessions, widening a divide among many residents.
content: WALLER COUNTY, Texas — At a roadside bar on farm road 359, where the sprawl of Houston gives way to horse stables and hay rolls, Cindy Schmid and her friend Gail Mikeska gather every Thursday to eat, drink and talk about everything: family, country music, the hard right turn of Texas politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Are water landings from space safe?
description: SpaceX has completed two successful earlier water landings, one at night.
content: Returning from the free-fall environment of orbit to the normal forces of gravity on Earth is often disorienting for astronauts. A water landing adds the possibility of seasickness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi
title: The Scientist and the A.I.-Assisted, Remote-Control Killing Machine
description: Israeli agents had wanted to kill Iran’s top nuclear scientist for years. Then they came up with a way to do it with no operatives present.
content: Iran’s top nuclear scientist woke up an hour before dawn, as he did most days, to study Islamic philosophy before his day began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron DePasquale
title: An F.D.A. panel’s vote deals the Biden administration’s push for universal booster shots a setback.
description: The panel recommended against blanket access to Pfizer boosters for those 16 and older, but urged offering them to those 65 and older and “at high risk,” a term that offers the White House some room to expand access.
content: The Biden administration’s push to make Covid-19 booster shots available to most fully vaccinated adults has been stymied for now by a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel’s recommendation that Pfizer boosters be made available only to those 65 and over and those at high risk of severe Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Covid-stricken Alabama had more deaths than births last year, a first in its recorded history.
description: “Our state literally shrunk in 2020,” said Dr. Scott Harris, the state’s health officer.
content: For the first time in Alabama’s known history, the state had more deaths than births in 2020 — a grim milestone that underscores the pandemic’s calamitous toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California governor says two of his children have tested positive for the coronavirus.
description: Gavin Newsom’s office said the state’s first family was “following all Covid protocols.”
content: SACRAMENTO — Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, who four days ago beat back a pandemic-fueled attempt to recall him, is “following all Covid protocols” with his family after two of his four children tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: When 7 Psychopaths Enroll at the Same School, Terror Ensues
description: In her latest column, Sarah Lyall weighs in on Vera Kurian’s twisted tale, “Never Saw Me Coming,” and two other new thrillers.
content: For a psychopath, Chloe Sevre is unusually astute about what social media can say about a person. “Will Bachman drinks too much and hangs out with people who don’t look after him,” she notes, analyzing the Instagram account of a fellow college student she intends to murder in Vera Kurian’s NEVER SAW ME COMING (Park Row, 400 pp., $27.99). “Will Bachman has 60 days to live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mady Camara and Ruth Maclean
title: In Senegal, Demand for Covid Vaccines Grows, but They’re Hard to Get
description: As rumors and misinformation about coronavirus vaccines gradually subside and the West African country emerges from a third wave, Senegalese are less reluctant to take a shot.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — When Mbaye Ndiaye, a science teacher in Senegal, arrived in his classroom after getting his first dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine in April, his pupils burst into a round of applause. Surprised, he asked them what they were congratulating him for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Do I Need to Clean Up My Attic Before I List My House?
description: Sellers should focus on the rooms where people spend the most time, but if you have the budget and time, staging the attic can offer a bonus for buyers.
content: Q: I am about to put my house on the market, and would like to feature the large, open, unfinished attic for potential finishing and use. Presently, it has unpainted plywood flooring. Do you have any suggestions for how to best stage this space, with minimal cost and work?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Dobbins, Natalie Kitroeff, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Edgar Sandoval and Miriam Jordan
title: How Hope, Fear and Misinformation Led Thousands of Haitians to the U.S. Border
description: Some left to find work. Others to escape violence or racial discrimination in other countries. But many believe ‘there is nothing to go back to.’
content: DEL RIO, Texas — They have arrived this week by the thousands, Haitians who had heard of an easy way into the United States. In what appeared to be an endless procession across the shallow waters of the Rio Grande, they carried mattresses, fruit, diapers and blankets, provisions to tide them over while they awaited their turn to plead for entry into America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Todd Gitlin
title: Was Occupy Wall Street the ‘Beginning of the Beginning’?
description: In “Generation Occupy,” Michael Levitin argues that the 2011 protest against income inequality shaped both the substance and style of American politics.
content: GENERATION OCCUPYReawakening American DemocracyBy Michael Levitin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Bennie Pete, Bandleader Who Kept the Beat After Katrina, Dies at 45
description: A tuba player and the leader of the Hot 8, one of New Orleans’s high-profile brass bands, he brought music to his fellow citizens in the difficult days after the storm.
content: Bennie Pete, a New Orleans tuba player who co-founded and led the Hot 8, one of the city’s high-profile brass bands, and dedicated himself to preserving the musical traditions of the Big Easy after Hurricane Katrina, died on Sept. 6 at a hospital there. He was 45.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: A Multifaceted Designer Gets a New Platform
description: Emmanuel Olunkwa is named editor of Pin-Up, the fashionable architectural and design magazine.
content: Name: Emmanuel Olunkwa
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: The Covid Crisis Is Now a Garbage Crisis, Too
description: Overblown fears that the coronavirus could be transmitted through surfaces have created a stigma around handling nonhazardous trash, experts say. Some recyclable waste has been junked or burned.
content: Across Brazil, recycling plants stopped running for months. In Uganda, a junkyard is short on reusable plastics. And in Indonesia’s capital, disposable gloves and face shields are piling up at a river mouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: A Political Road Not Taken in America
description: A brief look at the Confederate Constitution.
content: I have recently spent a lot of time reading about the Confederate government and the Confederate Constitution for a small project I’m participating in. It’s been a fascinating exercise in large part because I did not actually know that much about either. I have a strong working knowledge of the secession crisis, the Civil War and many of the personalities involved in both, but I was not as knowledgeable about the structure of the Confederate government itself or the particular provisions of its constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Three Weeks After Hurricane Ida, Parts of Southeast Louisiana Are Still Dark
description: As businesses and schools have reopened in New Orleans, ongoing power outages in communities just beyond the city put recovery out of reach.
content: NEW ORLEANS — For Tiffany Brown, the drive home from New Orleans begins as usual: She can see the lights on in the city’s central business district and people gathering in bars and restaurants. But as she drives west along Interstate 10, signs of Hurricane Ida’s destruction emerge. Trees with missing limbs fill the swamp on either side of the highway. With each passing mile, more blue tarps appear on rooftops, and more electric poles lay fallen by the road, some snapped in half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: In Portraits, Seared Memories of the Capitol Riot
description: In an interview, the photographer Jason  Andrew described the inspiration behind the portraits published in The Times this week and recalled his experience covering the violence of Jan. 6.
content: This week, The Times published interviews with six people — two lawmakers, two congressional staff members and two Capitol Police officers — who were inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. when rioters broke into the building. Accompanying those interviews are portraits taken this summer by the photographer Jason Andrew, who covered the violence in Washington that day for The Times. Below, he talks about his pictures, filming video portraits at 125 frames per second and his experience photographing the riot. This interview, the result of two conversations, has been condensed and edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: New Look
description: Peter Gordon’s grid requires one’s full focus.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Peter Gordon has been contributing puzzles to The Times like clockwork for over three decades. Most have been themed, and the ones that I remember the best have involved the elegant manipulation of letters to turn something ordinary into something surprising. This grid falls neatly into that category.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Lowenstein
title: Why Taxing Stock Buybacks Is the Wrong Fix for Executive Pay
description: The supposed link between buybacks and inequality is unproven.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in the news. This week, the financial journalist Roger Lowenstein weighs in on a plan by Senate Democrats to tax stock buybacks. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘It’s Always Going to Haunt Me’
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 18, 2021.
content: “There’s no manual on how to deal with an insurrection.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: The Inspiration4 flight showed space tourism’s potential and limitations.
description: A crew of everypersons showed what space tourism could become in the future.
content: When NASA owned and operated its own spacecraft, there was no chance it would rent out a Saturn 5 rocket or a space shuttle to someone else. But during the Obama administration, NASA decided to hire private companies to take its astronauts to the space station. One of the program’s secondary goals was to spur more commercial use of low-Earth orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Some Rich People Are Counting Their Antibodies ‘Like Calories’
description: Medical concierge services are offering coronavirus antibody tests as a perk, despite caveats about their usefulness.
content: Before Juhi Singh, 46, who owns a high-end wellness center on the Upper East Side, jetted off to the Amalfi Coast last month, she packed her bathing suits and left her 10-year-old son with his grandmother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Amanda Lucier
title: The Unconventional Weapon Against Future Wildfires: Goats
description: Lani Malmberg travels with a few hundred goats, which eat the tall brush and grasses that power Western wildfires.
content: When megafires burn in unison and harsh droughts parch the West, local governments, utilities and companies struggle with how to prevent outbreaks, especially as each year brings record destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: The N.F.L. Bets on Betting
description: Gambling on football has come out of the shadows.
content: If you watched the N.F.L.’s first weekend of action, there is a good chance you saw more ads for BetMGM, FanDuel and Caesars Sportsbook than you had ever seen in your life. The N.F.L. now has an official casino sponsor (Caesars) and partnerships with seven sports books. Nearly 60 million football bets were processed online in the United States last weekend — likely an all-time high — and the N.F.L. was probably thrilled about every single one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Coming up soon: The astronauts return to Earth.
description: Barring issues with the weather, the crew will splash down near sun down.
content: After three days in orbit, the crew of the Inspiration4 mission — the first trip to orbit where no one aboard is a professional astronaut — is headed home to Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: They Shunned Covid Vaccines but Embraced Antibody Treatment
description: Championed by doctors and conservative radio hosts alike, monoclonal antibodies for Covid are in high demand — even from those who don’t want a vaccine.
content: Lanson Jones did not think that the coronavirus would come for him. An avid tennis player in Houston who had not caught so much as a cold during the pandemic, he had refused a vaccine because he worried that it would spoil his streak of good health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: 100 Isn’t a Magic Number, So Why Is It Part of the Vaccine Mandate?
description: The threshold of 100 employees adds to a patchwork of small-business rules. It shows up in no other major small-business laws. The reasoning behind the number is a mystery.
content: When the Biden administration announced an upcoming mandate that employees be vaccinated or tested regularly at companies with 100 or more employees, business leaders responded with a barrage of questions. Among smaller companies, one loomed especially large: Why 100?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Víctor Manuel Ramos
title: Delta variant detected in 99% of U.S. cases, according to C.D.C.
description: The highly infectious variant of Covid-19 has contributed to a rise in cases, hospitalizations and deaths in the United States.
content: The extremely transmissible Delta variant of the coronavirus, which overtook all other variants in the United States just a few months ago, now represents more than 99 percent of cases tracked in the country, according to the data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Submarine Deal Gives Post-Brexit Britain Its Moment on the Global Stage
description: The British government played an early role in brokering the alliance with the U.S. and Australia to deploy nuclear-powered submarines in the Pacific, officials in London and Washington said.
content: LONDON — As relations between France and the United States sink to their lowest depths in decades, Britain has emerged as the unlikely winner in a maritime security alliance that has sowed anger and recrimination across three continents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Miriam Jordan
title: Biden Administration to Deport Haitians in South Texas
description: The U.S. will begin flying migrants back to Haiti and other countries on Sunday as President Biden struggles to manage an immigration system already buckling under record migration.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration announced on Saturday that it would swiftly begin deporting Haitians who have gathered in the thousands at the southern border in the past week after illegally entering the United States, as it struggled to manage an escalating crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Entire Presidential Agenda Rests on Expansive Spending Bill
description: A plan for the economy, education, immigration, climate and more binds disparate Democratic lawmakers, but the proposal risks sinking under its own weight.
content: WASHINGTON — No president has ever packed as much of his agenda, domestic and foreign, into a single piece of legislation as President Biden has with the $3.5 trillion spending plan that Democrats are trying to wrangle through Congress over the next six weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: A Metronome of Power Keeps the White Sox Humming
description: Jose Abreu is known for picking up checks, crowding the plate and driving in runs — a lot of runs. He is quiet in the news media, but his teammates have plenty to say about him.
content: CHICAGO — Going out to dinner with Jose Abreu, the reigning winner of the American League Most Valuable Player Award, can be a challenge. At least it is for his teammates on the Chicago White Sox who try to pay their fair share.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: ‘There Is Chaos’; Iran-Backed Militias Battle Activists in a Holy Iraqi City
description: Militia violence has driven antigovernment protesters underground and shaken Karbala, a city of gold-domed Shiite shrines.
content: KARBALA, Iraq — One night in May, Samira Abbas Kadhim was up late, waiting for her son. She poked her head out of the gate of their small house, looking for him down the narrow street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Víctor Manuel Ramos, Andrea Kannapell and Lauren Hard
title: Health experts voice support for opening booster access to older and at-risk Americans.
description: Some, however, wondered why the cutoff age is 65, and not 60.
content: American health experts spoke out on social media and other platforms on Friday and Saturday to applaud the likelihood that federal regulators could soon make Pfizer-BioNTech booster shots available for those 65 and older or at high risk of severe Covid-19, though some argued that the cutoff age should be lower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Secret Talks and a Hidden Agenda: Behind the U.S. Defense Deal That France Called a ‘Betrayal’
description: In meeting after meeting with their French counterparts, U.S. officials gave no heads-up about their plans to upend France’s largest defense contract.
content: The United States and Australia went to extraordinary lengths to keep Paris in the dark as they secretly negotiated a plan to build nuclear submarines, scuttling France’s largest defense contract and so enraging President Emmanuel Macron that on Friday he ordered the withdrawal of France’s ambassadors to both nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: As Climate Change Fears Grow, a Real Fight Over Fake Turf
description: A city’s decision to replace actual grass with a synthetic version sets off a conflict over the possible environmental and health risks of the move.
content: EAST ORANGE, N.J. — Residents near a small neighborhood park in New Jersey awoke early this month to the roaring sound of heavy machinery: A grassy field they had been begging officials to fix for years was finally getting a face-lift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lizette Alvarez
title: Adalberto Álvarez, Latin Dance Music Maestro, Is Dead at 72
description: He was known as the “Gentleman of Son” because of his infectious enthusiasm for repopularizing the genre considered the bedrock of the Cuban sound.
content: Adalberto Álvarez, one of Cuba’s most celebrated musicians, who as a bandleader helped revive and refashion Cuban son, a fusion of European and African styles and instruments that was vital to Latin dance music, died on Sept. 1 in a hospital in Havana. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Peter Williams, Who Painted the Black Experience, Dies at 69
description: His colorful works could be quite personal, or they could be blunt responses to police brutality or other news of the day.
content: Peter Williams, whose colorful paintings — sometimes humorous, sometimes disturbing, often both — reflected his own history, Black history and contemporary issues like police brutality and mass incarceration, died on Aug. 19 in Wilmington, Del. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: How Much Can You Trust That Generic Drug You’re Taking?
description: Competition for market share at rock-bottom prices has led to shortages, price-spikes, allegations of price-fixing, and substandard and even dangerous practices.
content: The American health care system is built on the idea that a pill is a pill. Generic drugs are considered equal to and interchangeable with one another — and also with the name brand. This gospel has existed since 1984, when a law known as Hatch-Waxman was passed, allowing companies to make drugs that had gone off patent without having to replicate the same expensive clinical trials. For the most part, all they had to do was prove that the generic was manufactured using good practices and worked in the body in a similar way, within an acceptable range.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kori Schake
title: The Deeper Problem Behind General Milley’s ‘Secret Phone Calls’
description: A recent story about the chairman of the Joint Chiefs’ actions during the waning days of the Trump presidency may not be as bad as it sounds. But there’s still cause for concern.
content: A new book reports that Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, improperly restricted the president of the United States’ ability to use military force and committed to warning China, an American adversary, of any impending U.S. military action against it. If the book, “Peril,” by Bob Woodward and Robert Costa, accurately recounts General Milley’s behavior, his actions could be an egregious series of violations of the norms that govern civil-military relations in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Despite Censorship and Poor Internet, Cuban Podcasts Are Booming
description: New audio shows made in Cuba are finding a rapt audience and upending the island’s hyperpartisan media landscape.
content: There has been little to laugh about in Cuba lately. But on a recent episode of El Enjambre, a weekly podcast produced on the island, the three hosts were howling at the latest form of censorship by the state-run telecommunications company.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Religious Beliefs and Abortion Laws
description: How religious belief affect abortion laws and vaccination.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 18, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 18, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about an appeal by the Justice Department to block a bankruptcy plan that would grant broad legal immunity to Purdue Pharma misstated the timing of OxyContin’s introduction to the market. It was 25 years ago, not 15 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times
